author: Duna Márquez
title: Alerta naranja en Mallorca | La dana deja ya intensas lluvias en la isla
text: Alerta naranja en Mallorca | La dana deja ya intensas lluvias en la isla En Galilea y Puigpunyent se han registrado 100 litros por metro cuadrado en tan solo dos horas El temporal que ha arrasado Valencia llega a Mallorca. Tras dejar precipitaciones intensas en Ibiza y Formentera, la dana comienza a descargar con fuerza en parte de la isla. La Aemet alerta de que los chubascos y tormentas pueden ser muy fuertes y localmente persistentes. El Govern reclama precaución a la ciudadanía y aconseja evitar los desplazamientos en carreteras. Las primeras precipitaciones y tormentas se han registrado en Calvià, Andratx y Cala Major, donde ha comenzado a llover sobre la una de la tarde. La peor parte, de momento, de esta dana se ha registrado en las localidades de Galilea y Puigpunyent donde se han acumulado 100 litros por metro cuadrado en tan solo dos horas. El temporal ha dejado también retrasos generalizados en el aeropuerto de Palma, con esperas de más de 60 minutos, según ha informado Aena. Más de 50 litros por metro cuadrado en una hora La [Agencia Estatal de Meteorología](https://www.diariodemallorca.es/tags/aemet/) recuerda que Mallorca se encuentra en alerta naranja por precipitaciones acumuladas de 50 litros por metro cuadrado en una hora, llegando a acumularse 120 litros por metro cuadrado en algunas zonas de la isla en pocas horas. Las lluvias se mantendrán hasta el sábado 2 de noviembre, alargándose el aviso naranja hasta primera hora de la mañana. Con el avance de las horas la alerta desaparecerá, pero las precipitaciones se mantendrán a lo largo del día. Parques, cementerios y pasos peatonales, cerrados El paso peatonal del paseo Marítimo de Palma entre el Palacio de Congresos y el Parc de la Mar permanece cerrado este viernes por el mal tiempo. Así lo ha informado el departamento de Carreteras del Consell de Mallorca en un mensaje en redes recogido por Europa Press. Cabe recordar que en Palma, desde las 14.00 horas de este viernes[ están cerrados los parques y los cementerios.](/mallorca/2024/10/31/cementerios-parques-palma-cerraran-14-111028434.html) El Govern pide "máxima prudencia" Ante la emergencia meteorológica para este día de Tots Sants, el Govern balear ha reclamado [“](https://www.diariodemallorca.es/nacional/2024/10/31/pedro-sanchez-reclama-poblacion-quedarse-111008018.html)[máxima prudencia” a los ciudadanos “las próximas horas y días”](https://www.diariodemallorca.es/nacional/2024/10/31/pedro-sanchez-reclama-poblacion-quedarse-111008018.html) por la alerta naranja decretada. Se recomienda que se tomen precauciones y mantenerse informado de la predicción meteorológica más actualizada. Las actividades habituales y al aire libre pueden verse alteradas. El Servicio de Emergencias 112 ha activado el Índice de Gravedad 1 (IG1) del Plan Meteobal por lluvias y tormentas en Mallorca y Menorca. title: Fiscalía presentó ante el Congreso denuncia constitucional contra Pedro Castillo
text: El expresidente [Pedro Castillo](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/tc-declaro-improcedente-demanda-de-habeas-corpus-para-liberar-y-reponer-como-presidente-a-pedro-castillo-noticia-1564616) fue denunciado por el nombramiento del excongresista [Daniel Salaverry](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/daniel-salaverry-poder-judicial-autorizo-inicio-de-juicio-oral-por-presunto-delito-de-peculado-doloso-noticia-1536737) como presidente del Directorio de Perupetro. [ Judiciales ](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales) Fiscalía denunció al expresidente por el nombramiento de Daniel Salaverry como presidente del Directorio de Perupetro. La [Fiscalía de la Nación](https://rpp.pe/peru/actualidad/fiscal-de-condorcanqui-denuncia-que-integrantes-de-comunidades-no-permiten-capturas-por-caso-de-abuso-sexual-a-menores-noticia-1564436) presentó ante el [Congreso](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/cesar-nakazaki-hay-contradiccion-en-sistema-de-justicia-con-prescripcion-de-delitos-de-lesa-humanidad-noticia-1564995) [de la República](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/cesar-nakazaki-hay-contradiccion-en-sistema-de-justicia-con-prescripcion-de-delitos-de-lesa-humanidad-noticia-1564995) una denuncia constitucional en contra del exmandatario [Pedro Castillo](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/tc-declaro-improcedente-demanda-de-habeas-corpus-para-liberar-y-reponer-como-presidente-a-pedro-castillo-noticia-1564616) por la presunta comisión de los delitos de negociación incompatible o aprovechamiento indebido del cargo y nombramiento ideal en agravio del Estado. El Área de Enriquecimiento Ilícito y Denuncias Constitucionales se encargó de presentar la denuncia contra el expresidente por el nombramiento del excongresista [Daniel Salaverry](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/daniel-salaverry-poder-judicial-autorizo-inicio-de-juicio-oral-por-presunto-delito-de-peculado-doloso-noticia-1536737) como presidente del Directorio de Perupetro. La denuncia constitucional considera que la Resolución Suprema No 002-2022-EM del 9 de enero de 2022 no estaría provista de legalidad, pues Salaverry no cumpliría con los requisitos. Te recomendamos TC declaró “improcedente” demanda de hábeas corpus para liberar a Pedro Castillo La denuncia constitucional contra Castillo Terrones llega luego de que el [Tribunal Constitucional declarara "improcedente" una demanda de hábeas corpus](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/tc-declaro-improcedente-demanda-de-habeas-corpus-para-liberar-y-reponer-como-presidente-a-pedro-castillo-noticia-1564616) presentada por su defensa legal que pretendía se declare su inmediata libertad y reposición en el cargo de presidente de la República. El máximo intérprete de la Constitución determinó que ni en la demanda ni en los demás actuados se advierten argumentos de relevancia constitucional respecto de la amenaza o la vulneración de los derechos fundamentales que justifiquen la declaración de nulidad de todo lo actuado en el proceso. Por tanto, el exmandatario continuará recluido en el penal de Barbadillo para cumplir los [ 36 meses de prisión preventiva](https://rpp.pe/politica/judiciales/pedro-castillo-poder-judicial-ordeno-36-meses-de-prision-preventiva-en-su-contra-noticia-1471534) ordenados por el Poder Judicial. Te recomendamos La entrada en política de Carlos Añaños Es una buena noticia que un destacado empresario como Carlos Añaños se haya adherido a un partido y anuncie su intención de contribuir a generar un consenso en torno a ideas de unidad, moderación y desarrollo. author: Tom Saunders
title: Hottest summer weather in five years predicted for coming days as heatwave engulfs half of Australia
text: An oppressive heatwave stretching across half the country from Darwin to Victoria will send temperatures soaring up to 15 degrees Celsius above average during the coming days. Maximums are predicted to exceed 40C across a broad swathe of the interior and east — the warmest summer weather in years for much of south-east Australia, including highs on Monday of 41C in Melbourne and 38C in Canberra. Across the eastern outback maximums will peak well above 45C, hot enough to challenge December records in a handful of western New South Wales towns. The severe heat follows Australia's warmest spring on record and is likely to be followed by additional bursts of hot weather through the Christmas and New Year period.Loading... Heatwave to engulf interior and east This December is fast becoming one of the hottest on record as frequent heatwaves sweep across the nation. While climate change and simmering seas surrounding Australia are having a background influence on the hot start to summer, the more immediate and direct cause of the current scorcher is the formation of a heat dome over tropical and central Australia this week. Under a heat dome, air sinks towards the ground where it compresses and warms up while also preventing cooler surrounding air from mixing in, a process which can prolong hot weather from days to weeks. The western edge of the dome already sent Perth to a maximum of 40.4C on Wednesday, the city's hottest December day in three years. The broad mass of 40C plus air is now shifting east and intensifying across central Australia and will peak over south-east states from Sunday to Tuesday as a north-westerly airstream carries the air mass well south. So just how hot will each day become? Here is a day-by-day guide on which areas should exceed 40C. Saturday: Northern SA, the inland NT and western Queensland. Sunday: Western Queensland, western NSW, most of the inland Northern Territory and South Australia.. Monday: Most of Victoria, western NSW, western Queensland, eastern SA and the NT. For many areas, including a handful of major cities, Monday's maximums are forecast to be the highest in years, including: - Mildura 46C, warmest day since December 2019. - Bendigo 43C, warmest day since January 2020. - Melbourne 41C, warmest day since January 2020. - Albury 43C, warmest day since January 2020. - Wagga Wagga 42C, warmest day since February 2020. - Canberra 38C, warmest day since February 2020 (if >38.0C). For smaller towns over the western Murray Basin, highs could even break December records, including 47C at Ivanhoe and Wilcannia. While eastern NSW also sweats through a heatwave from Saturday to Monday, the hottest weather for Sydney won't arrive until Tuesday when western suburbs potentially reach 41C. Cool change preceded by fire threat A cool and gusty south-west change will spread through southern states by Tuesday, and most of NSW by Wednesday, however, as is often the case, relief will arrive as a double-edged sword. The clash of opposing cold and hot air masses along the change will lead to a strengthening of pre-change winds and when combined with low humidity this will lead to extreme fire danger on Monday from eastern SA to central Victoria. Dangers may even approach catastrophic levels in western Victoria where winds will average 40 kilometres per hour, temperatures will reach around 45C and humidity will dip below 10 per cent — a combination which could cause fires to be fast moving and uncontrollable. So when can our capitals expect relief? Here is a breakdown of the likely timing of the cool change: - Adelaide, mid-afternoon Monday. - Melbourne, Monday evening. - Hobart, Monday evening. - Canberra, Tuesday afternoon. - Sydney, Tuesday night. Elevated risk of scorching Christmas While its too early for a precise forecast for Christmas Day, medium-to-long-range predictions of the general weather pattern weeks are more accurate than simply expecting the average weather or guessing. The Bureau Of Meteorology's (BOM) method for outlooks weeks and months ahead is to run their model 99 times and use the variation in results to indicate the likely weather. For the fortnight from December 16 to 29, the majority of those 99 runs show a strong swing favouring hot and dry weather across central and south-east Australia, and possibly further heatwaves. This doesn't guarantee a hot and dry Christmas Day, but the odds are firmly tipped against widespread rain and unseasonably cool weather. One hot day doesn't make a heatwave? The term heatwave is often thrown around flippantly when discussing hot weather, but the word in meteorology has a strict definition since heatwaves have claimed more lives than any other natural hazard in Australia and can affect infrastructure such as public transport and electricity supply. The BOM classifies a heatwave as a period when temperatures are unusually hot over three days, however the threshold for what's considered 'hot' varies by location and time of year. In simple terms the declaration of a heatwave is determined by comparing temperatures over a three-day period with: - What would be considered hot at that location. - The observed temperatures at that location over the past 30 days. The calculation therefore factors in the ability to adapt, for example, a 35C day will feel much hotter to a resident of Hobart in November than a resident of Brisbane in February as the latter will be acclimatised by both a sub-tropical climate and the recent passing of peak summer. However, it's not only daily maximums evaluated, minimums are also critical since warm nights prevent recovery from each day's heat while also allowing the next day to warm up quickly. Like most weather threats, heatwaves are sub-classified into categories to help communicate the level of risk. Low-intensity heatwaves are frequent during summer. Most people can cope during these heatwaves. Severe heatwaves are less frequent. They are likely to be more challenging for vulnerable people. Extreme heatwaves are rare. They can be dangerous even for healthy people who exercise or work outdoors. The current heatwave is classified as either low-intensity or severe in most areas, and extreme across the central NT.

author: #5791 wgs
title: 从洛杉矶骚乱看美国联邦政府与各州"权力的游戏"_军事频道_中华网
text:
加州洛杉矶骚乱引发的紧张局势正在向美国其他城市蔓延，旧金山、奥斯汀、华盛顿特区等地也都爆发了反对移民搜查的示威活动。此次白宫与加州政府斗争的一个焦点是美国联邦政府和州政府权力划分的问题，也就是美国总统是否有权在不经州长同意的情况下调动国民警卫队平息抗议。近年来，美国联邦政府与一些州政府的矛盾不断加剧，其中还掺杂了党派斗争的色彩。美国通过联邦制来明确联邦和地方之间的权责划分，但在政治极化不断加剧的背景下，美国制度设计的缺陷愈发明显。每当冲突加剧时，“内战”一词就会频繁出现在媒体上和政界人士口中。
6月10日，洛杉矶骚乱中的加州国民警卫队员。（视觉中国）
调动军队，总统权力有多大？
据《华盛顿邮报》报道，当地时间6月10日，美国总统特朗普警告说，与他为平息洛杉矶抗议而部署的4000名国民警卫队成员和700名海军陆战队员相比，针对联邦移民政策的其他抗议活动可能会“遭遇同等或更大的武力”。
作为美国三军统帅，美国总统理论上能够调动的“武力”有多少？皮尤研究中心6月6日援引美国国防部国防人力数据中心（DMDC）的统计称，截至今年3月底，除国民警卫队等预备役人员外，美国有132万现役军人，其中陆军人数最多，有大约45万人；其次是海军，约有33.4万人；之后是空军（31.7万）和海军陆战队（16.8万），而海岸警卫队和太空部队的规模要小得多，各自只有不到5万名现役军人。根据DMDC的数据，绝大多数美国现役军人（86%）驻扎在国内，14%驻扎在国外。在每个州工作的现役军人人数差别很大，加州拥有最多的现役军人，约有15.75万人。

author: , Pensacola News Journal
title: Rosamond Johnson Beach in Perdido Key celebrates Korean War hero
text: For so long, Johnson's Beach was just Johnson's Beach. We didn't know anything beyond that other than years earlier it was known as "the Black Beach" because of the tiring segregated system of the day. By the time the '70s and '80s swept it, Johnson Beach on Perdido Key had become a popular day trip beach excursion for folks of all races, though it was still a favorite for old Black families in the area who remember not being welcomed at Pensacola Beach so long ago. But almost everyone had one thing in common ‒ we didn't know Johnson's Beach was named for a real-life, honest-to-goodness teenage war hero whose bravery saved lives, sacrificing his own. Johnson Beach, a natural jewel on the Gulf of Mexico, honors Army Pvt. Rosamond Johnson Jr., a young African-American soldier who was only 17 when he was killed in action on July 26, 1950, becoming the first Escambia County resident killed in action during the Korean War. "As a little girl growing up in Pensacola Beach, I never knew the true meaning of Johnson Beach, why it was called Johnson Beach," said Erin Wilmer, Perdido Key Area Chamber of Commerce Military Appreciation Committee chair during her welcoming remarks Saturday at the 14th annual Private Rosamond Johnson Celebration at Johnson Beach on Gulf Islands National Seashore. "But as an adult, I learned the heroic story of this remarkable young man and it raised up in me a sense of pride. He is not only a family hero. He is an Escambia County hero." She could have gone on. Because Rosamond Johnson, who lied about his age and joined the Army at age 15, was an American hero. Previously: Rosamond Johnson died a war hero at 17. How he's still being honored 73 years later More than 100 people, including a U.S. Navy Color Guard Unit from Corry Station, attended the ceremony, which including a county proclamation and a wreath-laying ceremony at the Rosamond Johnson Memorial that was erected at Johnson Beach in 1996. Escambia County District 3 Commissioner Lumon May and District 1 Commissioner Jeff Bergosh attended the ceremony, as did Gulf Islands National Seashore officials. On the day Johnson was killed, he had already carried two wounded soldiers to safety. He was fatally wounded trying to rescue a third fellow soldier. Retired Navy Capt. Pat Everly, executive director of the National Flight Academy, delivered the ceremony's keynote address on a perfect Chamber of Commerce sunshiney day, as beachgoers ‒ largely families ‒ played on the beach behind the ceremony, kites riding lightly in a soft breeze against a cotton candy blue sky. Everly reflected on Johnson's young age. "He was 15 when he decided to pull the wool over the Army's eyes,'' Everly said. "I also looked back at my 15-year-old self in 1983." A bunch of us chuckled, not at Everly, but at the thought of our own selves going off to war at such a tender age, an when most of us were high school freshman, maybe sophomores. "Would I have had the courage to do what Private Johnson did?" he asked. "I don't know if I have the answer to that." Johnson's legend has grown in Pensacola since the memorial was erected and the annual ceremony established. But he was always a hero. Even if most of us didn't know it then. Raymond Reese knew from the time he was 1 year old. Reese, 75, is Johnson's half-brother. He was only 1 when his brother was killed. Before Saturday's ceremony, Reese was working the large grill behind the pavilion, where he and others were preparing food for guests following the ceremony. He and brother Marcellus Reese attended the ceremony, and are Johnson's lone remaining siblings, though he has other family members who have long celebrated Johnson's legend. "My brothers and sisters were raised up in, but a lot of people didn't know who he was or what Johnson Beach was," Reese said. "It's just a blessing to our family to see him honored. It's pride knowing someone from your own family went to serve and sacrificed." Reese was so proud, he would write essays in schools about his heroic brother and his legacy at Johnson Beach. "The teachers didn't believe me," he said. "They thought I was lying. So now, it's really gratifying to know he's appreciated."

author: Ashley Lopez
title: Nikki Haley didn't say slavery caused the Civil War. Now she's facing major backlash | KRWG Public Media
text: Nikki Haley didn't say slavery caused the Civil War. Now she's facing major backlash Former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley is facing significant backlash after failing to mention slavery as a driving force behind the Civil War during a campaign stop in New Hampshire. At an event on Wednesday, a voter asked Haley: "what was the cause of the United States Civil War?" She replied that the cause "was basically how government was going to run, the freedoms, and what people could and couldn't do." "I think it always comes down to the role of government and what the rights of the people are," Haley continued. "And I will always stand by the fact that, I think, government was intended to secure the rights and freedoms of the people." After Haley gave her answer, the voter told her that it was "astonishing" that she gave an answer "without mentioning the word 'slavery.'" Last night, [President Biden](https://twitter.com/JoeBiden/status/1740221284284256645?) said on X in response to a video of this exchange that the Civil War was indeed "about slavery." It was about slavery.— Joe Biden (@JoeBiden) [https://t.co/q9bTDvtPne] [December 28, 2023] During an interview with a local radio station on Thursday, Haley addressed what happened. "Of course the Civil War was about slavery," she said. "We know that. That's the easy part of it." Haley explained that she was interested in talking about what lessons should be drawn from the Civil War and defended her answer to the voter. "I know it's about slavery," she said. "I am from the South." Haley has a [complicated history](https://www.npr.org/2023/02/15/1157122486/nikki-haley-confederate-flag-race-president-2024) when it comes to issues of race. As a woman of color, her campaign was angling to strike a different tone on issues of race and identity – especially in comparison to her chief rival in the GOP primary, former President Donald Trump. As South Carolina's governor, Haley ordered the confederate flag be removed from the grounds of the state capitol following the 2015 shooting of Black parishioners at a church in Charleston in 2015. Haley also [condemned Trump](https://www.politico.com/news/2020/08/25/haley-trump-charlottesville-comments-401587) following the racist and antisemitic gathering in Charlottesville, Va., in 2017. (She also served as U.N. ambassador to Trump from 2017 to 2018.) The Republican Party, though, has been striking an overall different tone when it comes to issues of race and the country's history with slavery and white supremacy. Republican governors, including some of Haley's rivals in the race, have been [eliminating](https://www.npr.org/2023/05/15/1176210007/florida-ron-desantis-dei-ban-diversity) diversity and inclusion efforts in higher education, as well as [banning books](https://www.wusf.org/education/2023-06-01/politifact-fl-desantis-said-not-a-single-book-was-banned-districts-have-removed-dozens) that are about race. Backlash to Haley's comments comes less than three weeks before Republican voters start voting in early primary states. The Iowa caucus, the first primary contest, is Jan. 15. Haley's campaign, in particular, has had a surprising amount of momentum in the last several months. The once crowded field of presidential hopefuls has been shrinking ahead of early state elections but Haley has been one of the few candidates actually gaining more support. Just this week, there have been reports that Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis' campaign is [struggling](https://www.nytimes.com/2023/12/24/us/politics/desantis.html) and businessman Vivek Ramaswamy has [cut TV ad spending](https://www.npr.org/2023/12/27/1221828944/vivek-ramaswamys-campaign-has-slowed-tv-ad-spending-ahead-of-the-iowa-caucus). Trump has had a commanding lead in the polls in early states and nationally. Haley, however, has been the only candidate in the primary that has presented any sort of challenge for the former president.
